content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												With Dungeon Defenders 2 in Early Access, I'm not sure how many people are going to want to buy this game now but I gave myself a personal mission to review all the games in my library and that includes this one.I'll tip my hat and keep it as brief as possible.I recommend this game, this was my introduction to Tower Defense and it was lot of fun. I did not appreciate the fact that my Adept was mandatory at all times to solo things, since his defenses were the only ones I found strong enough to withstand the monster waves if I swapped to another character.The base game without spending alot in extra DLC doesn't offer a whole lot of levels or variety to keep things fresh. You'll cruise through those levels and then I found myself grinding the same level over and over for mana to buy gear because I sure wasn't going to see anything useful ever drop and I don't know how viable buying gear from other players is anymore.I know, I mostly listed negatives but this game WAS fun and WAS enjoyable. It's a great idea at it's core, it just didn't offer enough content even with the DLC (since most of those levels aren't worth farming for any reason), to keep my interest for terribly long. That said, I still burned tons of hours on this game. You can see that I believe.Dungeon Defenders 1 is a good game and it's fun to play but with the sequel in Early Access, I can only hope they see all the shortcomings they had with this game do a much better job with the sequel. This was a great idea, and I hope they build on it and make the sequel into what this game could have been.Don't pay alot for this if you're interested. You won't find it entertaing for long, but for as long as you do play it, you'll have fun with it. It was a really neat game that in spite of alot of fumbles in it's design direction, came out a blast to sink alot of hours into.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												After playing this for a few hours, I was loving it - no stopping me. I managed to reach level 35 on my Apprentice since I love the way I can just sit back and just repair my turrets without going in myself and fighting them like Warriors do. After that, level 70's started joining my game, so I thought "Oh wow some help is great!". After a few hours of them helping me grind the constant waves of monsters, I found myself at level 65. I started doubting why I even let them join me, not in a rude way but in a way that it started getting boring because I basically let them level up for me.Although this was a huge mistake, it was a mistake made by me. A mistake I didn't think would happen. The game I loved to play turned into a game I found so boring in just a few hours. I now have 3 level 100's since I didn't have access to other classes at the time. That's another thing - class selection. You have to buy DLC to unlock other class's to play, which can be a little bit over-priced just for a new class. For example, the Summoner DLC costs £2.99 just for one class!This game does seem a little bit like they are forcing you to buy DLC, since it always comes up on the screen when you load up the game, as well as when you pick the level nearly everything you have to pay for - but that's just my opinion.

												I'm conflicted. The base game w/ the DLC that came before the Eternia Shards Campaign is a total gem of a Co-op Tower Defense game that is totally worth your time and money.Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for what came after, as the game has over time been slowly transformed into a totally infuriating grindfest, plagued by poor decisions from the devs. Getting decent gear becomes a nightmare later on, due to negative stat rolls everywhere, random upgrade values and the vast quantities of garbage that drops.Nightmare difficuly was a tacked-on, unbalanced mess that made entire strategies null and void.  Character classes became either totally mandatory (Summoner/EV) or totally useless.However, I still recommend the base game to anyone who loves TD.  Hell, if you like endless grinding, I guess the DLC will float your boat too - just don't say I didn't warn you.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Summary: Orcs Must Die with experience and loot.Multiplayer: up to 8Completion: 20 hrsCards: NoCloud: No (but has online-mode saves)Dungeon Defenders plays out much like Orcs Must Die, where you attack waves of enemies emerging from several entrances by using towers, traps, minions, or just plain weapons. The game supports up to quite a few players, though four players is a safe bet for most maps.There's a lot to like about the game. It has a fairly good progression, as level-ups and items felt like large improvements in the early game. As you head towards the endgame though, item upgrades become much less frequent, and you may struggle on a number of later hardcore maps. Notably... there's a distinct lack of a proper tutorial. It does not teach you things like what your health bar and mana bar is. It does not teach you how to equip things. It does not teach you about sets. It does not teach you about upgrading items.Interestingly, the game allows you to switch heroes on the fly between rounds. Thus you can benefit from defenses another character you have, and then switch back to the one you want to level. It's an interesting idea, as it greatly simplifies the need for grinding, but at the same time, the early charm is entirely lost because you are packing high-powered defenses on a low level character and can just afk to victory with minimal strategy. Shrug. It's hard to say if the benefits outweigh the downsides.Each map allots you and your party a shared Defense Unit (DU) pool with which to summon  your defenses. I kind of wish there was a slight change to DU. I'd like it so that every character had a minimum DU devoted to themselves, and the rest would be a shared DU. That way all players would have at least some use for tower stats. Tower placement can get a but clumsy, since you can only summon within a short radius of your position. If the tower is too close to certain things, then you can't place it. All too often I find myself needing to cancel, reposition, and try to summon again, which can be problematic in combat when mobs may be attacking you. Unlike OMD there is no means to shape your enemy paths, but you can place structures that enemies will attack.The game likes to throw loot at you. A lot of it. You'll be seeing items left and right, polluting the entire field, and you won't know what to grab. Fortunately the game includes a rudimentary system that puts an indicator on items it thinks may be an upgrade for you, however more often than not the indicator is completely wrong. All the items you loot go to your item bank, which unfortunately is very poorly managed. You can create your own folders, but doing so shrinks your items visible per page. I would have really liked a way to sort and reorder items myself. At this point I would settle for nothing but a columns of text instead of the gigantic 12 icons at a time.This game offers one very nice feature most other games in this genre do not - the ability to change camera angles. By zooming in and out with the mouse wheel you can go seamlessly into first person, over-the-shoulder, and overhead views. I can't tell how much I wanted a feature like this in other games! There's even a 4th sort of view if you play as the Summoner, who can enter an RTS-like mode, which is even better. One handy touch is that if you die, especially in hardcore, you are allowed to free-roam the map while dead. It's nice to see the outside environment and to scout for other party members while in this mode.Dungeon Defenders offers five difficulties per map. You can probably ignore the first few, as those are almost always too easy. However, the game could probably use another difficulty between insane and nightmare. There is a sudden spike when you hit nightmare as you fight enemies with considerably more health, and the ability to air drop from anywhere. I had a lot of fun playing through the maps with some friends when the maps would just barely kick our butt, typically beating us on the last wave. Eventually we got our act together and can blow through almost everything, but the process of discovery was great. With the exception of one map, the game seems to run pretty well in multiplayer with minimal lag, so thumbs up for that!I am impressed at the variety of play modes the game offers. It goes well beyond the standard tower defense, including modes such as PvP, run a gauntlet, escort the crystal, and more. I much enjoyed the journey to reach high levels. It's a shame I can't really experience that again. It's a great multiplayer experience, I'll grant it that. I give Dungeon Defenders a 8.5/10, mainly knocking points for the Item Bank that is incredibly tedious to sift through. If you like tower defense + shooters, this game will serve you well.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2013
												Very fun and addicting game. Very simple concept too: You have to protect your Eternia Crystal while you fight off the mobs (goblins, orcs, etc). Though it may be a simple concept, it is difficult but that's what makes this game so fun! Very heavy on coop and it's almost impossible to do these levels yourself (it isn't impossible though.) There is the classic RPG-style level-ups and weapon upgrades. The tower-defense style gameplay with a third person/first person shooter camera, this game is an absolute must have for $15.The challenge and the feeling when you complete a level is one of the things that make this game so fun. There are the normal Campaign levels but along with those levels are the Challenge levels with different objectives such as fighting through monsters without your towers or fighting of goblins that fall at random spots in the map. There are different diffuculty level from Easy to Nightmare! Easy itself challenging when you start the game so you could just imagine Nightmare. This game is compatible with Steam Workshop so you can expect a lot of user-generated content along with the many DLC packs that come along with this game. Very fun game with very nice players. That's another thing; The Dungeon Defenders community is so helpful and nice and you almost never see someone badmouthing you or anything.Edit 11/26/2016: Still a great game!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Think of Dungeon Defenders as a four-player tower defense game combined with a third-person action title. You pick an avatar from one of four iconic classes: the Apprentice (aka Mage); the Squire (aka the Warrior); the Huntress (aka the Elven Ranger); the Monk (aka...well, the Monk). Each class has unique special abilities that they combine with specific defensive structures. The Monk, for instance, is a fighter class that can summon sphere-shaped auras that can do things like slow enemies or do damage over time. The Squire, on the other hand, summons more direct defenses, putting up walls and other direct damage defenses to stop enemies and give other classes a chance to put the hurt on.The goal, of course, is to survive all the waves of enemies. Each wave grows in number as you go on, and get increasingly difficult with each player that joins the fight (players can join mid-fight in between waves). Between each horde of enemies players get a chance to rebuild, upgrade and tighten up their defenses. The ultimate priority is defending the Eternia Crystal; if it falls, the level is over. Early in the campaign the levels have very simple layouts with only a single crystal and relatively few choke points, but things get much more strategic in the second half, where you're given multiple crystals to protect and a much greater variety of enemies to fight. A formula that you'd expect to become utterly repetitious manages to stay fun throughout because each level forces you to adapt to its unique layout and the various types of enemies you encounter. Crisis control is also important; when barriers start to fall, only a cohesive and communicative team will recover and hold the line.Each class has a role on the battlefield, but they're definitely not all created equal. Play a few games online, and you'll see why the Squire is the most popular class. Not only can he wreak havoc with his melee attacks, but his defensive structures can deal damage as well as stop enemies in their tracks. The other classes catch up to his prowess in the higher levels, but the Squire rockets ahead of other players early on since experience is regrettably not shared. The Squire just doesn't seem to have any major weaknesses – something I don't think I could say for any other class – and can be a little frustrating to group with when they're killing everything before you have a chance.With a good party, even a pick-up group made up of random strangers, I quickly found myself utterly addicted to Dungeon Defenders. Every level boils down the same objective, but as I said before, strategic adaptation keeps things interesting. What also keeps me hooked is the constant stream of loot and experience. Leveling up your hero and collecting that oh-so-precious booty keeps the proverbial carrot on a stick constantly dangling before you. I'm a sucker for that carrot, too, and it makes even defeat a bit easier. You see, losing a battle sucks in Dungeon Defenders, but you get to keep the spoils you find regardless. If you die you just equip the new hotness you've acquired, allocate points into stats if you leveled up, and go at it again.While acquiring loot hooks me, after it's in the bag, I'm left with mixed feelings. The look of your weapon changes – and man do they look awesome sometimes – but that's it. No matter what helmet you put on, or breast plate you don, your character looks the same. It may not sound like that big of a deal to everyone, but for RPG nerds like me, visually distinctive gear a big part of the appeal; I love loot grinding, but I want others to see how badass I am just by looking at me.On the upside, though, I love how you can level up weapons, giving you a reason to hang onto gear, and something to tweak in between the times when your character levels up. Killing monsters yields Mana, which you use to buy towers during each stage. After each level there's usually Mana left over, so you can use this – as well as any Mana you get for selling unneeded items – to put into your equipment. Each piece of equipment can usually be upgraded several times, allowing you to tweak its stats to better suit your playstyle. My Monk, for example, is all about Auras rather than direct attacks, so I constantly spend my excess Mana on equipment levels that allow me to better my role as a support class. Leveling up weapons is a nice way to keep me occupied when I'm not acquiring loot or getting experience, always giving me something to do to feel like I'm progressing.I can talk all day about how engaging a round of Dungeon Defenders is, but I can't emphasize enough how important it is to find people to play with. Whether it's four-player local or online play – or any mix thereof – you need to play with others. Playing alone is, well, lonely, and results in frustrating and boring gameplay. Mix together a few classes, and the competition of players who can do better and each level becomes a frantic frag fest.http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/10/31/dungeon-defenders-review

content:
Posted: December 6, 2011
												It's hard to put into words what genre this game is or really what the game is.  It has RPG elements, strong tower defense elements, and some MOBA/DOTA style elements.   It's also an amazing and fun game.You'll have access to four unique classes initially, though DLC unlocks a number more.   Each has their own play style for not just their towers but also their actual fighting.   This means you can enjoy a lot of replay value out of it, as you find different ways to beat the various maps on the higher difficulties with different kits.Additionally, you can swap characters between waves of enemies.  So once you grow your character pool, you can solo content on difficulties you would normally want a group for by just setting up defenses as a wider spread of classes.I've sank around 220 hours into this game and had a blast playing it.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Perhaps the best tower defence game out there as it also combines in the RPG elements we all love so much. The story line is simple and rather silly to the point that the squire character doesnt wear any pants, just heart boxers through the whole game so will no doubt induce a giggle or two from even the stoic faced individuals. The four playable classes are vastly different and all have their ups and downs making this game a must have for parties.The game is possible to win in single player, though easier and much more enjoyable to play multiplayer with your buddies where the roles and the types of defences set up are handled strategically by the whole party. Another great feature of this game is that new content is constantly getting released, some of it free, in fact the whole title seems to be slowly heading in the direction of a somewhat interesting MMO allowing the sale of personalised weapons, armour and pets on the global market. My personal rating for the game is 10/10 ^-^

You have to buy DLC to unlock other class's to play, which can be a little bit over-priced just for a new class. 												Before start if you are wondering which you should buy:  Dungeon Defenders 1 or Dungeon Defenders 2. I will recommend you to buy Dungeon Defenders 1 because Dungeon Defenders 2 doesnt have much content at the moment (March 1 2015) Dungeon Defenders 2 is get to level 25 and farm for legendary gear(Dungeon Defenders 2 is on alpha).Perfect game that let you build defenses how you want also you can put the stats where you want (for make a tower character or DPS character) which is really helpful i really recommend this game my favorite game so far. But it has one problem, which you can evade but sometimes you need to know about this game.The problem is the 99% of the events and best gear is hacked but they try to make it look legit or they just farm good gear duplicate it and sell it but usually the hacked gear is for level 83-100 but theres also  of all levels but thats quite  obvious because damage is 1 billion and stats are all 849 (add me and send me a message if you need help with gear or post it on dungeon defenders forums on: forums/trading/Item Check Thread and ask for item check                                                                       (  https://www.dungeondefenders.com/1/forum/11/trading  )).I have 600+ hours here and i started to get quite bored because ive already done everything but ive seen people with 1k+ hours and they still enoy it, the community is 7/10 because most are hackers or they kick you from games or they just insult you but most of the people is helpful, farming can get annoying doing the map over and over again but when you are high level almost everything is afkable so its fine (i had never found farming annoying but ive seen people getting mad of not getting a good weapon)Also theres some dlc's you should not buy like the skins and the valentines day dlc but if you want to go for all achievements buy valentines day dlc (valentines day have 2 maps which are pain in the♥♥♥♥♥the most annoying maps of all game) but should try and get all dlc's or it wont be as fun as it should.9/10 but if you are able to evade hacking as much as possible 10/10(read other reviews since i didnt covered 100% of the game)

Posted: December 1, 2013
												Dungeon Defenders (DD) is a great game to kick back and have fun on. Pros:     1. The game is well balanced in  every aspect.     2. Tons and tons and tons of weapons and armor.     3. Visually it quite nice, but of course it's not Crysis 3 quality.     4. Personally, after having played 200+ hours, I still find DD enjoyable.Cons     1. Unless you buy the dlc packs, you have (in my opinion) less than half of the full experience of  playing DD. having said that, you can buy all of the dlc and the game for $50 which I wish I had done when I originally bought the game.     2. Aside from the dlc, my only other complaint is that having some sort of tower characterization would be really neat and would add another level of strategy to the game. Summary: Dungeon Defenders is a very fun and easy to learn game that can be taken seriously with all of your friends spending the weekend with their computers, playing DD nonstop and kicking some goblin butt, or coming home after work or school and enjoying a relaxing hour of also kicking some goblin butt.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Greetings defenders or potential defenders,I really enjoyed this game. It is one of my favorites.You are a little hero like an apprentice, knight monk or huntress and have to defend the Eternia Crystals from the evil force in level-based towerdeffense roleplay. The mechanics and uniqueness of each hero and the combination of all are the key to victory. For example, the kobolds are running straight to your crystal and you have an apprentice and your friend a monk. You can easily build a blockade to buy time for the monk to summon an electric aura which shocks the kobolds to death. Well done little hero!With killing enemies and winning levels you can earn weapons or armor, which ups the damage of your electric aura or the durabilty of your spike blockades. Also your character can level up to become stronger. To make it a solo game too, you have before every wave a build phase, where you can build your towers and change to other characters, but the game is best played with a friend. For all who do not have one, you can also join random games or search in the community for friends.My biggest problem with the game is the fact, that the game can not played that good without DLCs. While some DLCs just add new characters and levels, some of them are needed to get some levels, so i would buy just the original game or directly all DLCs, so you really know, that you do not buy something you cannot reach without annother DLC. Another good fact about the producer studio is, that EVERY dlc is free for the fist 2 weaks after publication and that is definitly a thing you should support with buying this game.All in all I really recommend this game to all RPG and Towerdeffense fans, because it combines both genres perfectly in an awesome comic style game with a nice community and a modding system.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2011
												It's hard to put into words what genre this game is or really what the game is.  It has RPG elements, strong tower defense elements, and some MOBA/DOTA style elements.   It's also an amazing and fun game.You'll have access to four unique classes initially, though DLC unlocks a number more.   Each has their own play style for not just their towers but also their actual fighting.   This means you can enjoy a lot of replay value out of it, as you find different ways to beat the various maps on the higher difficulties with different kits.Additionally, you can swap characters between waves of enemies.  So once you grow your character pool, you can solo content on difficulties you would normally want a group for by just setting up defenses as a wider spread of classes.I've sank around 220 hours into this game and had a blast playing it.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2011
												One and a half thumbs up. I give the developers of Dungeon Defenders serious props for mixing two of my favorite game types: action RPG with Diablo-esque item hoarding, and competent, serious tower defense. Double-props for making this game available on portable platforms (for free too!), however the game is far from perfect. The RPG aspect is basically broken, as players develop min-max tower and combat characters just to war-stomp matches... This provides little challenge, and even less reward. Maps that seem "random" and chaotic at first eventially become efficiency matches, as you try to maximize your score. If there was more of a random element to this game, and if players were given incentive to experiment with character design, this game would be one in a million. As it stands the game is a lot of fun, but only for a little while. At $15 you can't go wrong however. Don't get this game if you have a download cap however, as this game updates ALL FILES, DAILY.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Rating: 8.5/10Overview: Third Person Tower Defense The Good:+ Bright colorful graphics. + The amount of enemies, towers, special effects, heroes on screen is amazing.   + Variety of heroes each with their own towers and abilities. As you level up you can spend stat points on health, damage, tower damage, rate of fire etc. You can build characters more suited for building towers or heroes more focused on  dealing damage. + lots of items to customize your hero + 26 maps (with all dlc)  + 49 challenges (with all dlc). Some of the more basic challenges include no towers, harder enemies, etc. Surprisingly many of the challenges are pretty unique and are a lot of fun to play if you ever get bored of the standard tower  defence game.  + Successfully combines tower defense and action rpg. + Every map in the game has 5 difficulty levels, in addition to hardcore mode option - if your hero dies during combat you have to wait for the round to be over before you respawn. Pure Strategy option - You can only use towers to defeat  the level. Survival mode - Fight wave after wave of enemies.  + Controller support although it is much more preferable to play with keyboard and mouse. + Healthy online multiplayer community. Everybody I played with were friendly and helpful.  The Average:The difficulty especially with solo play is odd, The first round is usually the hardest because you have to run around and set up your towers properly. On harder difficulty levels you have a time limit to do this making things even  harder. However once you make it past the first few rounds the game because incredibly easy almost to the point where you no longer have to do anything.   The game features plenty of items to equip. The problem however is that items are grouped into specific character level restrictions in order to equip them. Many of the more powerful and useful items can only be equip at level 74 and  above.   Some of the multiplayer games can be boring especially if there are overpowered people playing. The Bad:- Achievements can only be collect online. The good news however is that you can still play solo by setting up a private match. The bad news...you just played for over one hour fighting wave after wave of enemies. One more wave and you  will finally get the achievement you always wanted.....finally the moment arrives.....connection lost..... ConclusionThis game features a staggering amount of content, you could easily play this game for hundreds of hours if you are really into tower defense games. This game does a lot of creative things with the tower defense genre and it is a lot of fun to play especially with other people.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Think of Dungeon Defenders as a four-player tower defense game combined with a third-person action title. You pick an avatar from one of four iconic classes: the Apprentice (aka Mage); the Squire (aka the Warrior); the Huntress (aka the Elven Ranger); the Monk (aka...well, the Monk). Each class has unique special abilities that they combine with specific defensive structures. The Monk, for instance, is a fighter class that can summon sphere-shaped auras that can do things like slow enemies or do damage over time. The Squire, on the other hand, summons more direct defenses, putting up walls and other direct damage defenses to stop enemies and give other classes a chance to put the hurt on.The goal, of course, is to survive all the waves of enemies. Each wave grows in number as you go on, and get increasingly difficult with each player that joins the fight (players can join mid-fight in between waves). Between each horde of enemies players get a chance to rebuild, upgrade and tighten up their defenses. The ultimate priority is defending the Eternia Crystal; if it falls, the level is over. Early in the campaign the levels have very simple layouts with only a single crystal and relatively few choke points, but things get much more strategic in the second half, where you're given multiple crystals to protect and a much greater variety of enemies to fight. A formula that you'd expect to become utterly repetitious manages to stay fun throughout because each level forces you to adapt to its unique layout and the various types of enemies you encounter. Crisis control is also important; when barriers start to fall, only a cohesive and communicative team will recover and hold the line.Each class has a role on the battlefield, but they're definitely not all created equal. Play a few games online, and you'll see why the Squire is the most popular class. Not only can he wreak havoc with his melee attacks, but his defensive structures can deal damage as well as stop enemies in their tracks. The other classes catch up to his prowess in the higher levels, but the Squire rockets ahead of other players early on since experience is regrettably not shared. The Squire just doesn't seem to have any major weaknesses – something I don't think I could say for any other class – and can be a little frustrating to group with when they're killing everything before you have a chance.With a good party, even a pick-up group made up of random strangers, I quickly found myself utterly addicted to Dungeon Defenders. Every level boils down the same objective, but as I said before, strategic adaptation keeps things interesting. What also keeps me hooked is the constant stream of loot and experience. Leveling up your hero and collecting that oh-so-precious booty keeps the proverbial carrot on a stick constantly dangling before you. I'm a sucker for that carrot, too, and it makes even defeat a bit easier. You see, losing a battle sucks in Dungeon Defenders, but you get to keep the spoils you find regardless. If you die you just equip the new hotness you've acquired, allocate points into stats if you leveled up, and go at it again.While acquiring loot hooks me, after it's in the bag, I'm left with mixed feelings. The look of your weapon changes – and man do they look awesome sometimes – but that's it. No matter what helmet you put on, or breast plate you don, your character looks the same. It may not sound like that big of a deal to everyone, but for RPG nerds like me, visually distinctive gear a big part of the appeal; I love loot grinding, but I want others to see how badass I am just by looking at me.On the upside, though, I love how you can level up weapons, giving you a reason to hang onto gear, and something to tweak in between the times when your character levels up. Killing monsters yields Mana, which you use to buy towers during each stage. After each level there's usually Mana left over, so you can use this – as well as any Mana you get for selling unneeded items – to put into your equipment. Each piece of equipment can usually be upgraded several times, allowing you to tweak its stats to better suit your playstyle. My Monk, for example, is all about Auras rather than direct attacks, so I constantly spend my excess Mana on equipment levels that allow me to better my role as a support class. Leveling up weapons is a nice way to keep me occupied when I'm not acquiring loot or getting experience, always giving me something to do to feel like I'm progressing.I can talk all day about how engaging a round of Dungeon Defenders is, but I can't emphasize enough how important it is to find people to play with. Whether it's four-player local or online play – or any mix thereof – you need to play with others. Playing alone is, well, lonely, and results in frustrating and boring gameplay. Mix together a few classes, and the competition of players who can do better and each level becomes a frantic frag fest.http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/10/31/dungeon-defenders-review

Posted: January 29, 2014
												This is one of the best action tower defense games out there! This game mixes tower defense, third person action, and rpg elements and they all fit together perfectly. Choose from many different heroes who all play differently from eachother then start going through wave after wave of enemies as you gather better equipment and level your hero. Dump points into tower defense, or your heroes powers or balance the two. The RPG and loot system has you coming back for more and the added coop play is perfect for playing with friends or meeting new friends playing with other people. You won't be dissapointed in this game and it is worth all the money I paid.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2012
												Dungeon Defenders is a moderately fun distraction, but only with friends. The gear-and-level based community is about as friendly as the developers are trustworthy. With stolen designs from multiple games and ripping off artists that did work for the game, it shows, with a haphazard, overly cartoonish and unpolished design. Still, some people might enjoy the visual style, which I could only handle barely. The redeeming qualities lie in mowing down tons of bad guys, but really... there are too many cons to this game. The constant (almost every day) updates, the endless DLC(which i personally find to be way too expensive for their underwhelming payoff) and repetetion leaves a lot to be desired, but in the end, it's a like-it-or-not title. 5/10

content:

												This game is fantastic. I appreciate it for shaking up the stale Tower Defense genre. The coop is tons of fun, with multiple classes to choose from and plenty of levels to play through. Letting players run around the environment was a great choice. This game is what I judge other Tower Defense games against.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I used to play a lot of Tower Defense maps when I played Warcraft III. (both Reign of Chaos and Frozen Throne) I found it highly entertaining, yet it sometimes became repetitive with the snap-to-grid build locations. A few years have passed since I last touched Warcraft III, but my love for Tower Defense games never faded. I would always have at least one or two on my iPhone.Then one day I met Dungeon Defenders.Not only do you have the freedom to build your towers or traps nearly everywhere on the map; you have your own Hero that you can control and engage in combat. Each Hero has their own types of Towers and Abilities, making the fun for a wide variety of people. The best part of this game is, you don't have the fight the waves of monsters alone. You can bring 3 friends with you to defend the Eternia Crystals. I highly recommend this game, even if don't know much about Tower Defense, because you can spend your skill points on your Hero itself, instead of the towers.Always be sure to look at some gameplay before you consider purchasing, it can make or break your decision to buy it.

Couldn't understand anything, died all the time and ended up being level 42 in 10min. This was actually a bad thing as I had no idea how to arrange my stats, and the game will not allow you to level-up partially. Same for Items, I feel forced to make uneducated permanent choices as I level up things.Take this game if you have close friends to play with with same level-range characters. Otherwise, stick to Sanctum.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2013
												With "679 hrs on record", I can vouch for this being a super-addictive game. A basic play through on the default difficulty actually doesn't take that long. Nightmare mode on the other hand is damned near impossible. Even if you do manage it, you'll probably feel compelled to do it better next time. That's what kept me playing: trying to obtain the ultimate defense.The game is Tower Defense crossed with 3rd Person Shooter. As you level up you can choose to increase the stats of either your hero or towers, or maybe a bit of both. Increasing stat points along with loads of unique item drops, the possibility of two characters having the same configuration are slim to none. There is now also a PvP arena, so you can test out the metal of your uniquely configured hero.The negative side to Dungeon Defenders is that it's "secure" ranked server really isn't secure at all. You'll sometimes encounter players who have gear with impossibly high stats that are clearly hacked. I've reported several hackers and scammers to Trendy myself but they don't seem too concerned with the problem. Most likely because they're now focused on Dungeon Defenders 2, which is sadly nothing like the first game.. (it's a DOTA clone).------------------Edit:Dungeon Defenders Eternity Edition is now out. It's much more secure as most things are now done server side instead of locally.  I strongly advise that you purchase the Eternity edition over this one.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												First off, I'm not that kind of person that can write deep meaningful reviews, in fact, this is my very first one, but I do believe the amount of ingame hours can speak for my words here.So, this game... great choice for those who like tower defence genre, with extra rpg elements and item grinding, which may not be the cup of tea for everyone, as at some point it becomes necessary, but it offers replayability for those who enjoy hunting for better gear. Looking at the game at the moment, its further development was handled from the Trendy developers to a community team, so it's expected to get some new fresh content to even more expand the game. Overall, very addictive and enjoyable game, and for the price as it is listed, worth the investment.However due to how old this game is, its active playerbase is slowly fading, so it may be difficult to find company at times in multiplayer. And also, to experience the full potential of this game, it requires acquiring most of the DLCs along with this game. These are the only cons I could think about.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 1
												I have owned dungeon defenders since it came out and i enjoyed the game alot. at first dungeon defenders was a fun game for me to play with friends and attempt to progress past the current level I was stuck on. However, as more and more DLC were added that were basically necassary to buy in order to have the best gear and fight the most powerful enemies, the game became progressively worse.Nightmare difficulty, while a fun experience simply does not feel rewarding, as the gear that drops is almost never better than the gear you will already have. Another point here that could be good or bad depending on what kind of player you are is that at nightmare difficulty, it is nearly impossible to beat the levels solo. You almost always either need to have every character at max level with good gear or play with 2 or 3 other people who have the characters that you do not.Possibly the biggest problem with dungeon defenders is the community. The community is teeming with hackers and pretentious high level players. There were many hackers who would hack gear and then sell this gear for real money to new players or young people who didn't know better. People who bought hacked gear by accident would not only be ousted by the community but would also be banned by Trendy Net from playing online multiplayer, while the people who sold the gear in the first place would almost never get banned.If you are going to buy Dungeon Defenders, I would reccomend playing only by yourself or with friends, and I would also reccomend that you stop playing the game once you have gotten past the campaign on insane difficulty. The game is enjoyable enough until that point, with many different strategies and many different fun ways to play. Past insane difficulty, the game becomes a constant grind that almost never feels rewarding.TLDR: The game is fun playing with friends until you defeat insane difficulty, past there the community is terrible, the game doesn't feel rewarding and the flood of DLC is a money grab that is basically essential to buy to get anywhere past mediocre gear.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This FPS has it's up and it's down. The difficulty skyrockets after setting it from easy to normal, which is terrible difficulty curve mechanics on the developers parts. Add the fact that people who can play on normal just hoard all of the loot to themselves in a pinch-penny fashion. Us easy players can't get anywhere if the normal players can't share the loot.All in all however, at least there's a neat pet simulator, which competes with TF2's on par hat simulator.I'll give it a green/blue rating.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Waste of your time. Endless mode is boring as hell and there is no real end-game goal besides making your char even more ridiculous. You will have unlocked every skill after 5 minutes and from then on there is no change in playstyle. You can't change skills, you will need to level another char. This is not replayvalue, it is a time-sink. There is no synergy between the towers and abilities and the amount of towers and traps which can be placed is laughably low.If you enjoy passive gameplay and have a lot of time to spare (and got 2-3 friends who've got the same problem) then I would recommend you this.However, if you cherish satisfying slaughter of hordes of enemies, interesting levels and fewer limitations on how to equip your character and do the levels, I strongly recommend Orcs Must Die 2. Even without a loot-system, it offers more flexibility, more char customisation and more ways to beat the various levels (which are ten times more varied than these).3/10 would not buy again.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Got this in a humble bundle for like five bucks with all DLC. Definitely not worth more than that, certainly not the total of $65 it costs right now. Game is incredibly poorly optimized. Several endgame maps just do not run well at all, non-hosts get unplayable rubberbanding and monster/damage lag. Every map uses basically the same strategy and requires you to have endgame geared copies of all the heroes. Grind is absolutely absurd. All drops are pure RNG, all stats/values are randomized. There aren't minimum threshholds so look forward to getting a bunch of terrible godly (lv 60) gear on lategame NMHC survivals that need 10x the stats as the gear they drop. If you can get it for pocket change its alright for that, but its not worth anywhere near the price on steam.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders is a game that I developed a love-hate relationship with. On one hand, it's a class-based multiplayer action RPG with tower defense elements and is a lot of fun to play with friends of similar levels. However the game has many elements which tend to be detrimental to the experience. For one thing, the game is very grind-heavy. Whether you're getting new gear, or gaining a new level, or trying to get a really obscure achievement for a rare pet, the grind will make you feel like you're playing a Chinese MMO. Second, the sheer amount of player levels means unless all players are the same level, someone will feel like one is carrying the other. Third, much of the content of the game is locked behind so much DLC that it would give Train Simulator a run for its money. Fourth, the game is not very fun playing solo and you cannot even get achievements solo unless you play online.Dungeon Defenders is a really huge timesink, and I know plenty of gamers who enjoy that, but at the end of day I never felt a sense of real accomplishment despite the sheer amount of "progression" I made in my characters. At higher levels I grew bored with the sheer monotony of the game, watching my towers decimate entire rows of bad guys who only know how to march like lemmings over and over again. In the end, I found the action-oriented nature of Orcs Must Die and Orcs Must Die 2 to be far more fulfilling for my tastes.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												READ IF YOU ARE TRYING TO DECIDE BETWEEN DD1 AND DD2!Ignore my hours because i've played this for countless hours on consoles as well. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME UNLESS YOU HAVE FRIENDS WHO WILL PLAY IT WITH YOU. This game is very basic and will get VERY boring if you just play it alone. It took me a couple hours to get a character from lv 1-73 alone and then after just a day I felt like I was running through this game too quickly, but once I went Online with some friends it was like an entirely new game. My friends and I have spent countless hours on console and on PC blasting away wave after wave of enemies, upgrading, learning new strategies and just goofing off. If you are looking for some hardcore MMO style game, then this is NOT for you. If you enjoy a casual rpg that you can play with friends then look no further. IF YOU ARE HAVING A HARD TIME DECIDING BETWEEN DD1 or DD2 or DD:Eternity , STAY AWAY FROM DD2 and Eternity , just buy this one. DD2 is a complete nightmare and is heading no where, that game is a complete train wreck. DD: Eternity is a terrible money grab, sneakily released by the devs to make more money, it is exactly the same as DD1 but has a terrible amount of bugs and problems and when the devs realised this they abandoned the game and did not finish it. Just stick with DD1! It's your best bet of the series and the only game of the series worth buying!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												This game was really addictive...Lots of Hack and Slash action mixed with RPG elements (leveling, attributes, equipment sets, different armor and weapons, different qualities for armor and weapons...) and a good example of what the Tower Defense genre is all about...Sadly, the developers created many problems for endgame, with 3 hours+ grinds that can effectively give you completely useless stuff. The random attributes range for the best equipment start from MINUS (...yes, negative attributes), and for a game that expands it's longevity on top of equipment grinding... it's one unforgivable mistake.Avoid like the plague, or at least avoid the awfully balanced Nightmare Mode.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												/Edit. My review used to be negative. I had lost all of my characters seemingly for no reason. A while after I wrote this review another steam user told me in the comments that the same thing had happened to them and that they fixed it with support. (Thanks Rain!:) They showed me where to contact support and after contacting them they quickly restored my lost stuff. The reason I lost my stuff was that I played on a mac and a PC. This is the first negative review I have written. At first I really enjoyed this game, liking the gameplay a great deal. I WOULD have written a positive review for this game. But let me explain: One day I logged in on my mac (Yeah I have a mac) and found all my characters were gone. I quit the game and later logged on my PC and all my progress was gone on both. I did a little research and Trendy Net would once have done something about this, but the team responsible for manually reinstating characters was gotten rid of, because of Dungeon Defenders 2 and cost. I was not very high level and I could get back there, but what if it happened again? This is a fun game but you could lose all you characters.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												It's over four years old now, and some of the newer TD games are a bit faster paced, but it's still a very solid 3rd person TD game with hundreds of hours of content so long as the player doesn't skip ahead by purchasing items from other player's shops or getting power-leveled.The only significant problems with it are related to the recent patches which the player community has been involved in.  -- First, the MAC and Linux versions still haven't been updated after many months, so they can't play with people who use the Windows version anymore.  Hopefully, that'll eventually be solved, but we've seen no progress there yet.-- Second, when bugs are introduced, it takes months for them to be solved.So, as long as you're on Windows, and you don't mind a bug here or there, the current version of the game is great.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												At first, it looked to very fun and enjoyable, but it gets boring very quickly. The reason why its so boring is because you do the exact same thing over again, you build defenses to order to protect the crystal. I played this with no other friends and it gets boring. If you're going to get this game, play it with friends because the singleplayer is just not that fun. Its only fun in singleplayer if you're a find of grinds. Some other problems with the game are stupid design choices. For example, I'm playing on normal difficulty, in the build phase, and playing as squire. During the build phase you walk around and build defenses, simple right? Its not so simple when your character moves at 2 mph. I guess they made it like this for the harder difficulties where you are timed in building stuff. When your playing on normal however, your not timed, instead you have all the time in the world to build defenses. So why then does your character move at half-speed, doesn't make sense. Antoher problem is that to start the wave, you have to go ALL the way back to the cystal. Why can't we do it remotely?I guess they made it like this to make it more "challenging" but to me, I find annoying. For all these reason combined I couldn't recommend this game. Only get this game if you can play with friends or you are a fan of grinds. So glad I got this game during a sale...

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2012
												A really engaging and active tower defense game. While you don't get many toys to play with (5 "towers" per character plus 2 skills), the character depth comes from how you upgrade your stats. Most of the difficulty comes from tower placement and is easier to read than most tower defense games. Thankfully since there are fewer turrets than normal when you lose a map you aren't left thinking "should I have used the flamethrower turret or the spinning blades?" Although it seems simple/boring at first, there is always something to do on later maps; whether you are upgrading/replacing/repairing turrets or tanking/sniping/aoeing waves of mobs down, everyone is always doing something.I would recommend this over similar titles (like Sanctum) because of the large amount of maps, diversity of game modes, hero flexibility and customization, and non-rage inducing difficulty.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												Read this before downloading this game, you will know if you want it or not.Pros:- It is not Pay to win, you can easily get just as good as people who did buy some dlcs.- Even without dlcs, this game can provide you with HOURS upon HOURS of gameplay. (Im at 47 hours atm and I'm not even close to being satisfied.)- The graphics are great for a game of such age, not so great that you need a super computer to play though.- (Opinion) The concept is truly amazing, a 3d tower defense were you can help your towers get the job done.- 4 default characters (No dlc), and many more added with dlc.- Trendy Net (The Multiplayer Provider) is still keeping an eye on the community and banning modders.- There is an infinite amount of content to play on steam workshop.-  Deeper well on Insane Survival HC mode. <3 Cons:- Some (NOT ALL) of the community is filled with horrible trolls who can ruin hours of your gameplay.- Some grinding is required at higher levels, may result in boredom.- Some characters (Monk) are practically impossible to play solo, you must have a team.- Some bosses are imbalanced.- Dungeon Defenders II is garbage.- The story kinda leaves off on a big cliff hanger.- ^^^ You can't finish the entire story without a DLC.- Some of the (Recommened level) recommendations are extremely incorrect. Some levels are either way easier or harder than the requested.BIGGEST CON OF ALL: Nightmare Ogres..... they sooo beautiful.... til u see dat health bar..... >.<

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												This was a really stupid game that I had an absolute blast playing with friends. It had just enough depth for us to be able to work out how to do well, enough levels of difficulty to be challenging, and was simultaneously casual enough to just jump into and play. It was poorly balanced and had really unpleasant controls; a non-existent story and boring, samey enemies, but to play it with friends not really taking it seriously was huge fun. Totally worth if you have a group to just ♥♥♥♥ around, so like if it's on sale and you can get four copies, totally get it and try it out. But definitely NOT worth full price or playing alone.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2011
												A mix between a Tower Defense and an Action-RPG. There are four different heroes to pick and each one can build different towers. As you progress through the levels your hero gains Experience Points, acces to new towers and can level up. You can upgrade your hero's attributes (or those of your towers), there are tons of items and pets which fight for you - all of which you can upgrade at the "Forge" in order to make them more powerful and trade them with other players. Dungeon Defensers has a Co-op mode for up to 4 players, 4 difficulty settings, various challenge missions for bonus items and items exclusive to the challenge. There currently are 4 game-modes: CAMPAIGN - normal game, SURVIVAL - endless waves of enemies, PURE STRATEGY - only towers can attack, and MIX MODE which completely randomizes enemy waves when playing survival mode.I had a ton of fun with this game already and really recommend giving it a try if you like the concept of Tower Defense games. There is a DEMO, too!

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												This game can be addicting (at least for me it was).Although, it seems like no one really plays online anymore; however, at least there is local play. Issues I've had with this game, mostly because I am an achivement/trophy junky, the achievements recieved in game doesn't seem to log onto the steam account. Thus, the trophies I should have gotten from this game is not showcased on steam. This is very disappointing and distracting for me (ocd achievement junky and all). Other then that there are many maps, and lots of new creative challenges I've yet to buy or download. It was the first far more interactive defenders game I came across. Most are eagle view of the entire map and you plays towers or what not to defend, but this one you create a character and recieve armors, weapons, and pets. Maybe one day when I make enough money I'll invest in the purchasable maps and challenges. Until then, happy gaming.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												In Dungeon Defenders, the gameplay is good, as there is a fair bit of hack and slash but also tower defense. Not to mention that hacking this game isn't worth it. It has a good campaign that is not very deep, but the game also is a tower defense, not a blockbuster game like Call Of Duty Black Ops 2. The coop experience allows a whole new experience each time.One time,you may just breeze by it like nothing happened. Amp up the difficulty and you may just escape the hands of death. The difficulty is a good challenge for all players.  Luckily, the DLC is fairly priced.  About 3 dollars for a character with there own skills and fleshes. (i.e. the Summoner) This game suits alot of players. Like, I play summoner because i like the RTS feel of the game. The summoner feels way different than, say, the Knight. different towers,  Skills, and voices.  I would say that the game's cheap little price is well spent. Those who hack the game and say it sucks just haven't played co-op.  So pick up the game and I'll see you there!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												In Dungeon Defenders, the gameplay is good, as there is a fair bit of hack and slash but also tower defense. Not to mention that hacking this game isn't worth it. It has a good campaign that is not very deep, but the game also is a tower defense, not a blockbuster game like Call Of Duty Black Ops 2. The coop experience allows a whole new experience each time.One time,you may just breeze by it like nothing happened. Amp up the difficulty and you may just escape the hands of death. The difficulty is a good challenge for all players.  Luckily, the DLC is fairly priced.  About 3 dollars for a character with there own skills and fleshes. (i.e. the Summoner) This game suits alot of players. Like, I play summoner because i like the RTS feel of the game. The summoner feels way different than, say, the Knight. different towers,  Skills, and voices.  I would say that the game's cheap little price is well spent. Those who hack the game and say it sucks just haven't played co-op.  So pick up the game and I'll see you there!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												I have had this game for years and played it off and on. I love this game. You have many options in how you can build a map and the character you choose to play with. Whether you want to go full DPS or full Build Stat, you make the decision. The story is  good as well for what the game is based on. Some people WAY over think it and become bent out of shape with the story and how HORRIBLE it is. The higher levels you have to work for later in game. And the DLC I think is a plus because it adds variety to hero selection and map chocie. The game has been out for a whiile so Update are very few now. Modded weapons and hackers are a problem but what games dont have them. Just Screenshot, ,Kick, Report, and Move On.  Though I dont like how the Head developer treats his staff in a recent forum I found, I Love the game. I give it a 8.5-10 As of now due to the lack of updates and Lack Violation Penalty.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Go in to Dungeon Defenders expecting a few dozen hours of good co-op and you will get your money's worth. There's a lot going on with characters, towers and loot drops galore and a few runs through the campaign will provide good entertainment. It does get fatiguing after a point though, and while it presents a huge amount of replayability, after a point difficulty ramps up excessively, the equipment grind sets in and the sparkle fades. Well worth it while the lustre remains, but rest assured you will eventually find yourself tiring of it and looking elsewhere to avoid frustration and boredom setting in.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												This was a really stupid game that I had an absolute blast playing with friends. It had just enough depth for us to be able to work out how to do well, enough levels of difficulty to be challenging, and was simultaneously casual enough to just jump into and play. It was poorly balanced and had really unpleasant controls; a non-existent story and boring, samey enemies, but to play it with friends not really taking it seriously was huge fun. Totally worth if you have a group to just ♥♥♥♥ around, so like if it's on sale and you can get four copies, totally get it and try it out. But definitely NOT worth full price or playing alone.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Great Game,As a lot of games I like I own this on a few of my steam accounts as well as on my XBox 360. I love that you can play on Steam with your wired XBox 360 controller with the same controls as on XBox 360. On the computer version of the game you get a lot more characters, and more content then you do with the 360 version but both to me is well worth it. If you can get a few copies of this game for you & a few friends its well worth playing. If your looking to play with others online fairly without everyone using mods, hax, etc... You may find yourself pretty disappointed. Its even worse on XBox 360 as most players have some type of hacked item that deals more then 5 million damage making the game rather pointless to play. Shamefully there are always some ........ who want to ruin a great game by feeling the need to cheat. If you like to cheat, great game! Otherwise get a few copies for yourself & a few friends so you can enjoy game play as it was intended.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												This is my favorite game of all time. Dungeon Defenders is a tower defense-ish game. I hate tower defense games because they are rigid in where you can place what towers. Everything is in a grid & only certain types of towers are allowed in certain slots. DD is not at all like that. You are trying to prevent the mobs from destroying your crystal & you use towers and your hero to stop them. That's about where the similarities end. You can place your towers anywhere on the map, facing any direction, in any combinations. You can switch between characters to use towers from the Apprentice & the Squire, for example, but then play on your Monk. You cannot stack towers, but other than that you have nearly complete freedom in how you place towers. You have a maximum number of "defense units" with each tower using a particular number of DU to build so you need to be strategic with what towers you'll use where.Unfortunately the later levels are unplayably laggy. The other drawback is that the terrain appears to disappear on the latest waves in the large maps if you have a large group & the host's upload speeds aren't obscenely fast. For my purposes there was still plenty to do in the game other without hitting these bugs.Still, there is a ton of replayability and many, many different goals to work towards depending on your preferences. Increasing the difficulty doesn't feel like you're just doing the same map over & over as the mobs change as you increase difficulty which makes you change your build to handle the new mobs. The story is brief, but fun. The combat is intuitive. The menus are not at all intuitive, until you get used to them. I have never enjoyed a game even half as much as this one.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Dungeon Defenders is an fps/tower defense where you control a character that participates in the fight against those trying to unleash an ancient evil.PROS:+Art style is very comforting and makes you feel at home in a warm tavern+Good blend of tower defence strategy and player killing power+Lots of DLC+Hard to get bored, there is always something you can do+Insane and Nightmare difficulties prove a legitamate challenge to us mere mortals+So many pets and weapons to collect+Each of the 4 base characters have enough builds and replayablity to not get bored of them in the first couple hundred   hoursCONS:-Wyverns manAll in all, a very solid game. I wish you luck in protecting the noble lands of Eternia!

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
The Definition of GrindOh hey this game looks different! It's a tower defense RPG game in 3rd person. You can play with your friends, collect loot like weapons & armor. You can even buy pets that will support you and your towers as well.Sounds good right?Well... for a while. Starting off there is a campaign which is pretty much the same story as every medievel fantasy movie, show, book, goddam 5 year olds imagination in existance. So skipping the story (which there is pretty much none of) yeah its fun for a while to find new gear and level up but towards the end of the campaign I started feeling like... "I'm just doing the same stuff over & over again" then I moved into the bonus levels and well.... did the same thing over & over again.The problem is its fun when you start because you have to work out the stratagy and how to use your towers best. You level up, put points into your stats and find new gear that slowly gets better and better. I do like the RPG elements, they work great... but the levels are all the same... Maybe I'm repeating myself to much but well now you know what its like to play the game. There might be a boss here and there that you need to work out how to combat but there are just so many levels I bearly got through the campaign and main DLC levels before I was completely over it.On a side note there are 106 achievements. Of which I completed 26 within 52 hours of game time. You would have to live this game to possibly get close to 100% as a lot of them require you to beat levels on Nightmare which is crazy difficult and requires massive amounts of replay to get to a level where you and your towers are strong enough to even attempt. 5.8/10- 2MuchGrind4Me

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												On sale for about three or four dollars this is a great game no matter what.However that being said the game is mainly meant for playing with friends I feel, and while that would be all good and fine the problem I find with the game is that is it VERY short.  I've bought this game on both the PC and PS3 now and while I didn't get far in the PS3 here I found that the game is more for those that don't mind replaying the same stage over and over with little change up if any, and under whelming maps.  Another problem I have is they don't offer much for late game players, as in if you buy it now there is a butt ton of DLC that you'll have to pay for, though for those of you that already bought it before then, lucky you.  With all this said and done that's all of the flaws, it's still fun for about ten hours before you find out that they expect you to just replay the same maps or pay up for more, and it is a very pleasing to the eye game, just don't play public matches, keep things private.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												Dungeon Defenders is the first game to combine hardcore tower defense with hack-and-slash RPG elements to make a truly unique experience, and a massive replay value to boot! There's always a score to beat, whether it's someone else's or your own.Easy to learn, hard to master: With difficulty levels ranging from Easy to the ultimate difficuly, Nightmare, you'll always find a challenge no matter how powerful or skilled you become.  Item drops are generated using a RNG akin to that of Diablo's for a seemingly infinite variety of loot. The maps are wonderfully done, and enjoyable to build on, as well as simply explore.Each DLC Trendy Entertainment conceives is usually free within the first week of its release, and the game itself goes on sale relatively frequently.The main downsides I've noticed are that you will probably get bored of the game once you've tackled all the content and challenges, and later drops can vary greatly in quality giving you the feeling you might be stuck in a sort of 'limbo'. Due to the division of tower and character stats, you will probably end up having "builder" and "combat" characters, so you will end up having to switch out during different phases. Personally I would have preferred stats and their parallel counterparts to be the same, as well as giving each player their own fraction of a stage's total build units, which would keep every character relevant and allow every player to contribute to and be involved in both aspects of the game.Overall though, Dungeon Defenders is an even greater value than its price denotes, and with this much content, I can promise time well spent too. I look forward to seeing the improvements Dungeon Defenders 2 will likely make to this experience.

Posted: August 8, 2014
												A lot of you have been begging me to review this game so here it goes... Dungeon Defenders is a top down third person FPS with a hint of MMO without the MM. In this game it is all about time management. You must systematically run from jail cell to jail cell defending each of the prisoners in the dungeon from real above the shoulders type stuff, such as scoliosis, herpes, and racoons. it is very difficult, not to mention the bonus level where you yourself is placed into a jail cell and during shower time you must defend your dungeon. 10/10

												Dungeon Defenders is ridiculously fun and addicting. I played with four friends during the relatively short campaign. You acquire tons of loot for your class (there is a selection of 4 for free). My only gripe with this game is the endless dlc which has more than half the story. The characters you can buy are sometimes the same as one of the free ones but slightly different. Overall I would recommend this fun game theres fun missions, cool bosses, replaybility, and strategy.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												A good tower defense, RPG-like game.. With friends.+ Well made cel-shaded graphics+ Good performance across a wide variety of PCs+ Good assortment of characters who play differently enough from each other, to foster a feeling of uniqueness+ Some maps can get very intense+ Will leave you with a real feeling of satisfaction after successfully defending a difficult map+ Setting up your defenses and strategizing your approach adds a lot to the experience+ Good character progression and decent gear upgrades as rewards+ Good replay value- Horrid community, for the most part- Can get frustratingly difficult on some maps- Playing solo will guarantee a loss unless you are exceptionally skilled at the game, and have a very high leveled character- Some defensive structures can be overpowered on some mapsAll in all, this is a good experience, assuming you have friends who are willing to play this with you. If you don't have any, I would think twice before picking this up84/100 Recommended with some caveats.

Posted: December 4, 2015
												The game alternates between waiting and using a few abilities ad nauseum. The attempts at a metagame are balanced in the wrong kind of way, where your decisions do not feel meaningful because they're all more or less correct. Rewards are bland and do not feel like they open strategic avenues, which is a death knell for tower defense games. The art design is well done and if you play this, make sure you have co-op partners.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Very great game.It's addictive, and really challenging (even if you're maximum level). It gives me a feeling as if I should play it to the very end, and even further. I personally love the art style and gameplay strategy, and how it gives you a choice on what you can do.Imagine it sort of like Castle Defense. Monsters come in, you need towers to take them out, but you are also able to attack the monsters yourself. However, monsters will attack your towers, and you if you get in their way. The best way to win is to work with others (agreeing with them on tower positions, repairing their defenses, etc), and to always think out your strategy before going in guns blazing (even at that, you'll still probably die if you think you can take them all on your own).However, one issue is that there is a lot of DLC. If you want some additional content, either have your wallet ready or buy the new Dungeon Defenders game (however, that game cannot be played without an internet connection).But if you only want four playable characters and around twenty levels and challenges (each), this should be for you.Another thing is that some online players (mostly newer ones) don't plan their strategy first and immediately want to get to killing. This can be a problem, since they steal the mana (what you use for abilities, towers, defenses, healing, etc) and start the wave before I can do anything.It's always good to talk to your team first before you do anything. Arguing over defense units (your limit of defenses) can be common, but usually it can be resolved.Overall: It's a great and fun game.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Like tower defence games? Then this is a perfect game for you!Dungeon Defenders takes a spin on tower defence games by putting you right in the middle of action. It is a unique concept and is amazingly fun with friends. There are many challenging levels which can get easier as you level up your heros and gear. (There are also pets :P) which gives you a lot of gameplay.After a while though this game can get boring as sometimes the strategies and fighting gets repetative. You can choose a different hero however I can't really be bothered grinding the levels again.PROS: This is a very fun game with friends which offers a variety challenging levels, loot and leveling systems.CONS: Not as fun playing alone. Gameplay can get repetitive and feel grindy.7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2013
												DLC Defen... *ahem* I mean Dungeon Defenders is a third person cooperative multiplayer game that pits you against waves of enemies. Your team's goal is to protect the crystal. The gameplay is mediocre as best; it's not terrible but it's not particularly compelling. I'm sure at moments it could be fun but I was not ultimately impressed.  What really turns me off about this game is the staggering amount of DLC and it's certainly not all cosmetic (ie, hats and skins although there is that sort of stuff too). I only purchased the stock game and I found that the majority of the content it presented to me was "locked" and requiring a DLC purchase. Even at loading screens it would hawk DLC at me that I do not own. As a player I found this to be entirely disrespectful and it made me feel like I purchased a demo. The mediocrity of the game's flavor left the sour taste of shameless DLC enterprising as the dominant flavor.Not RecommendScore:4/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Now that I've played my fair share of this Game I'd like to give you guys a more in-depth Review of this Game. (Thanks to Valve for the new Review Feature)The Main Goal is to defend a Crystal from Waves of attacking fantasy creatures. You can pick one of several classes like the Apprentice, a Wizard Trainee that can summon Magic Towers to help in defending the Crystal. A Huntress who can lay traps to slow the advancing troops or stop them dead in the tracks and a lot more. It's a bright and colourful mix of "Tower Defense" and First/Third Person Action RPG". (You can change from 1st to 3rd person).The Game has seen a steady support from the developers and offers a near endless amount of items ranging from Swords, Bows, Guns, Rainbow firing ponies and Seahorse Pets to small Goblin Cupids. The Campaign is a lot of fun to play together with friends, I can highly reccomend it to you guys if you're looking for a fun game for your group to play with. It's easy to get into and soon you'll be spending hundreds of hours (just like me) finding the perfect strategy and build for your character for each and every map of the Game. There's also tons of side-missions that cruelly twist the Objective to bring in some extra difficulty. How about defending a Portal that teleports around the map? Or how about trying to defend a Portal in a Town that is slowly being flooded while you have to solve riddles to lower the water levels ? All that and much more is waiting in this game.This pretty much sums it up so far, again, I can highly reccomend this game. It's extremely addicting, has a cute graphic style, an amazing soundtrack and lots of replayability... and the added Steam Workshop feature only adds to the latter!Give it a go!  5/5 from me

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												What to say, what to say?Well, let me begin by saying that, despite my scarce amount of time playing it on Steam, I have been withthis game from the beginning. I watched it develop and grow with a smile, because this sod was once a promising bunch of ore, and now it's become the most well-crafted blade I can think of for its genre (neck and neck with Sanctum 2).Everywhere from the cheesy humor to the need for a quick thinking mind when the wizards begin swarming your Slice-N-Dice blockades, this game is probably my ultimte favorite of all time, hands down. Well, maybe besides Starbound, but that's besides the point.I daresay that this game is wholly worth every cent they ask for, and I mean the game entirely, DLC and everything, not just the game itself. Pricey to do it that way, but I digress.MY only complaint is the player base, which I know to be something beyond Trendy's control. Otherwise, hell yeah, I would totally recommend this gem.
