content:
Posted: August 7, 2013
												A very fun game if you like tower-defence games and want to have that crossed with RPG elements and a multiplayer aspect. They scale the levels up with the more people there are and the higher levels too. Each different character has different types of things used to slow down and kill enemies such as the mage can set up towers that cause damage, the warrior also sets up damaging traps, the rogue sets up mines and the monk creates auras which can reduce the enemies strength and defence when they walk through the auras, even their speed. Everyone i've played with has been very nice with a great community.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dungeon Defenders is by far the most intuitively challenging FPS RTS / tower defense game that I have ever played. Offering multiple echelons of difficulty, each with unique gameplay effects and stat augmentations, the enemies become hilariously difficult in an endless onslaught of Serious Sam proportional challenge. The first enemy miniboss introduced is the Ogre, noted for its brutish form and high hp. He was not of much difficulty, but when web-shooting spiders began falling from the sky while buffed mages shot fireballs around my head as I jumped over a kamikaze kobold that nearly 1hit k/o'd me, I knew I had gotten somewhere in the game. Thankfully, my heal aura fills my hp in 5 seconds flat. Good thing the game allows you to employ all of your characters in a single game!The updates bring endless new content, and I was lucky enough to recieve this copy as a gift including them all. I perosnally enjoy playing them all. All it takes to beat them is better gear. Once you have the strategy down, all the maps play out the same, but watch out! A single goblin might eek by your defenses unless you keep a watchful eye, oneshotting your crystal on the hardest difficulties..If that's not good enough, go figure that it lets you host your own shops in an intuitive manner that facilitates real economic activity and sets price standards for stable economic interaction as well. The online play is fundamentally necessary to beat difficult maps and challenges. It is crucial to have a compotent partner with good communication to beat the game, which is something I like personally to see. Dungeon Defenders 2 gets an A+ by my standards in terms of multiplayer features, weapon generation functions, and game progression.

												One of the best tactical/combat games that i have ever played. Dungeon Defenders is a game about heros teaming up to protect their eternia crystals from the incoming mobs of monsters. Each hero is unique and can summon different types of defenses and each hero has their own special abilities. The goal of DD is to clear all the dungeons and challenges and to ultimatly reach level 100. Since the higher your level the better items you can equip to your heros. Hopefully this helped but if it didn't then Google or youtube can help XD.I just wanted to say that I love this game!!!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												The trailer looks quite nice so I bought a 4-pack seeing that this game can be played together with friends. However the second I enter the game I got a bad feeling that I'll dislike the game. Unfortunately my instinct was right. Developers made this game 3-D with switchable first-person/third-person perspectives. However if you are using first-person view and try to defend, it'll temporarily switch to third-person.The minimap must be invoked through some hot key and isn't displayed by default. And as some other reviews mentioned, the graphics is way too colourful and well, it might be suited for some kids but it just makes me dizzy.If you want to buy this game, make sure you watch someone play it first, or I'll just recommend Orcs Must Die 2.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												As a tower defense/fps hybrid, this game does not appear to put a lot of effort into the tower defense part. In fact, most of my time is spent collecting mana (how original) and consistently evaluating millions upon millions of items, instead of strategizing towers and whatnot. Basically, it's Borderlands (2?), but instead of an open-world adventure, you're just killing a bunch of ogre-thingies. And that's the other thing - this game seems to emphasize weapon setups and strategies instead of anything else. Or so it seems.If you like evaluating a bunch of different weapons and armor and resistances and all that sort of stuff, then go ahead and go crazy with this. But if you're looking for any sort of tower-defense strategy, the game falls short compared to the other components in defending this crystal (also, how original). *sigh*
